Theophrastus, e. 71 , speaks of asandy cyanus, the “ bergblau” of the Germane, our mountain blue.

The “Lesur-stein” or male cyanus, the deep blue lapis armenus, is most probably the “Luam” of Theophilus.

The Persian “ Lazoard” blue, is probably the origin of the term ‘⁴ Lazur.” Beckmann states that the Persians are very fond of ultramarina but that Persia only produces the blue copper ore, (the male cyanua) and that the real lapis lazuli is found in the mountains of Tartary in Eucharist, extending eastward from the Caspian¹.
